risk_factors.reasoning: An 18-year-old male is considered a young adult and may be more prone to risk-taking behaviors.
Living with both biological parents in an urban area may provide some level of social support, but it does not necessarily mitigate the risks associated with being arrested and convicted.
Having a GED certificate and not enrolling in college suggests that this individual may be limited in their education and employability options.
Holding only one job during the year suggests some level of employment stability, but it is not necessarily indicative of future success or security.
The past four years have seen increased substance abuse (marijuana and cocaine), which may indicate a higher risk of recidivism.
Being currently living alone suggests that this individual may be less likely to experience the stabilizing effects of marriage or family relationships.
Considering God has something to do with what happens to him personally may suggest a higher level of motivation and resilience, but it is not necessarily indicative of future behavior.
Being 6 feet 1 inch and weighing 195 lbs suggests physical strength and potentially increased aggression, which may increase the likelihood of recidivism.
